intro: Chamaesciadium spinosum, commonly known as the spiny sandmat, is a perennial flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It belongs to the family Amaranthaceae and is characterized by its low-growing, mat-forming habit with spiny stems and lance-shaped leaves. The plant produces small, clustered flowers that range in color from white to pink, typically blooming in late spring to early summer. It thrives in sandy or gravelly soils and is adapted to arid environments, making it a hardy species suitable for xeriscaping. Its unique morphology and drought tolerance make it an interesting subject for both ecological and horticultural study.
